## MATHEMATICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 242, 318]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[730, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 216, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 696, 732, 728]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) of masses \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively are free to move in a horizontal straight line on a smooth horizontal plane. \(P\) is projected towards \(Q\) with speed \(0.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) . At the same instant \(Q\) is projected towards \(P\) with speed \(1 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) . \(Q\) comes to rest in the resulting collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 425, 156]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(P\) after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1400\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling at constant speed up a straight hill inclined at \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\sin \alpha = 0.1\) . There is a constant resistance force of magnitude \(600\mathrm{N}\). The power of the car's engine is \(22\,500\mathrm{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 134, 517, 154]]<|/det|>
Show that the speed of the car is \(11.25 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
The car, moving with speed \(11.25 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\), comes to a section of the hill which is inclined at \(2^{\circ}\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 148, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 556, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
Given that the power and resistance force do not change, find the initial acceleration of the car up this section of the hill.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 571, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[369, 84, 668, 262]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 280, 920, 330]]<|/det|>
A particle \(Q\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) is held in equilibrium by two light inextensible strings \(PQ\) and \(QR\). \(P\) is a fixed point on a vertical wall and \(R\) is a fixed point on a horizontal floor. The angles which strings \(PQ\) and \(QR\) make with the horizontal are \(60^{\circ}\) and \(30^{\circ}\) respectively (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 343, 405, 361]]<|/det|>
Find the tensions in the two strings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 343, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 87, 890, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 333, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
An elevator moves vertically, supported by a cable. The diagram shows a velocity-time graph which models the motion of the elevator. The graph consists of 7 straight line segments.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 381, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
The elevator accelerates upwards from rest to a speed of \(2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) over a period of \(1.5 \mathrm{~s}\) and then travels at this speed for \(4.5 \mathrm{~s}\), before decelerating to rest over a period of \(1 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 428, 920, 478]]<|/det|>
The elevator then remains at rest for \(6 \mathrm{~s}\), before accelerating to a speed of \(V \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) downwards over a period of \(2 \mathrm{~s}\). The elevator travels at this speed for a period of \(5 \mathrm{~s}\), before decelerating to rest over a period of \(1.5 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 146, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 616, 508]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the elevator during the first 1.5 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 491, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 666, 148, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 666, 798, 685]]<|/det|>
Given that the elevator starts and finishes its journey on the ground floor, find \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 667, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The combined weight of the elevator and passengers on its upward journey is \(1500\mathrm{kg}\). Assuming that there is no resistance to motion, find the tension in the elevator cable on its upward journey when the elevator is decelerating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 85, 675, 184]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 203, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(5\mathrm{kg}\) is being pulled along a rough horizontal floor by a force of magnitude \(X\mathrm{N}\) acting at \(30^{\circ}\) above the horizontal (see diagram). The block starts from rest and travels \(2\mathrm{m}\) in the first \(5\mathrm{s}\) of its motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 266, 146, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 266, 432, 285]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 266, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 505, 144, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 811, 526]]<|/det|>
Given that the coefficient of friction between the block and the floor is 0.4, find \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 272, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
The block is now placed on a part of the floor where the coefficient of friction between the block and the floor has a different value. The value of \(X\) is changed to 25, and the block is now in limiting equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 335, 845, 352]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the coefficient of friction between the block and this part of the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 353]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 650, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that the minimum velocity of the particle is \(-125 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 81, 787, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 253, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) of masses \(0.5 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(m \mathrm{kg}\) respectively are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley which is attached to the top of two inclined planes. The particles are initially at rest with \(P\) on a smooth plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal and \(Q\) on a plane inclined at \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The string is taut and the particles can move on lines of greatest slope of the two planes. A force of magnitude \(0.8 \mathrm{N}\) is applied to \(P\) acting down the plane, causing \(P\) to move down the plane (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 363, 146, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 363, 717, 382]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(m = 0.3\), and that the plane on which \(Q\) rests is smooth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 394, 395, 413]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the plane on which \(Q\) rests is rough, and that after each particle has moved a distance of \(1 \mathrm{~m}\), their speed is \(0.6 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\). The work done against friction in this part of the motion is \(0.5 \mathrm{~J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 136, 517, 155]]<|/det|>
Use an energy method to find the value of \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
